metadata.title: Durable superamphiphobic nano-silica/epoxy composite coating via coaxial electrospraying method

ull Length Article
urable superamphiphobic nano-silica/epoxy composite coating via oaxial electrospraying method
iaoyan Li, Hui Li, Kai Huang, Hua Zou, Dengguang Yu, Ying Li, Biwei Qiu, Xia Wang ∗
chool of Material Science and Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, 200093, China
r t i c l e i n f o
rticle history: eceived 21 August 2017 eceived in revised form 5 November 2017 ccepted 27 November 2017 vailable online 2 December 2017
a b s t r a c t
In this study, a durable superamphiphobic nano-silica and epoxy composite coating with good environment resistant was successfully fabricated. Fluorinated nano-silica with low surface energy was prepared by in situ sol-gel method, which can be stably dispersed in the solution. Applying fluorinated nano-silica dispersion as sheath and epoxy solution as core, fluorinated nano-silica/epoxy superamphiphobic composite coating was prepared by a coaxial electrospraying method. Fluorinated nano-silica with uniform nano-size was distributed evenly on the micro epoxy particles, showing a special micro-nano hierarchical
eywords: uperamphiphobic luorinated nano-silica poxy omposite coating
structure. Nano-indentation shows evident improvement in modulus and hardness of fluorinated nanosilica/epoxy composite coating than that of raw epoxy. In addition, durability of the superamphiphobic coating was assessed by performing harsh chemical environments immersion and scotch tape test.
© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
oaxial electrospraying
. Introduction
Superhydrophobic and superamphiphobic surfaces have ttracted extensive interests in the past decades owing to their nique self-cleaning property [1,2]. Unlike superhydrophobic suraces, superamphiphobic surfaces are repellent to both water and rganic liquids, and thus, have wider potential applications, e.g., nti-fouling, anti-sticking, anti-corrosion protective, self-cleaning, tc [3–5].
Superamphiphobic coating was prepared by various methods, uch as chemical vapor deposition [6], electrochemical etchng [7], sol–gel [8], and solution–immersion method [9]. The ssential elements of superamphiphobic surface are hierarchical icro/nano-patterned structures and low surface energy [10–12]. eanwhile, previous studies confirmed that hierarchical surface tructure was the most crucial factor, for the multiple length cales can trap air more effectively than those single scale texture 13]. Usually, large or special equipment were needed for building he required micro-nano patterned structures. Furthermore, flurinated materials with lowest surface energy were mostly used n large-scale fabrication of superamphiphobic surfaces [14,15]. herefore, reducing the amount of fluorinated substances to lessen he costs and the resulting environmental risks is necessary. In
∗ Corresponding author. E-mail address: wangxia@usst.edu.cn (X. Wang).
ttps://doi.org/10.1016/j.apsusc.2017.11.241 169-4332/© 2017 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
a word, preparing a large and durable superamphiphobic surface effectively remains a challenge.
Recent studies shown that inorganic substances were the best choice for preparing polymer-based superamphiphobic surfaces [16–18]. The polymer-based hierarchical surface could be generated by using different inorganic materials, such as nano-silica [19,20], carbon nanofibers [21], titanium dioxide [1], and others [22]. Epoxy is a widely used thermoset polymer matrix to obtain a stable and durable coating with good bonding effect [23–25]. Epoxy coating has attracted much attention due to its low consumption of volatile organic compounds, decreased flammability, improved safety, low cost and easy clean up with water [26,27]. While the large-scale application of the superamphiphobic surface may be limited by the intrinsic brittleness of epoxy. Silica nanoparticles are good candidates for improving the mechanical properties of epoxy composites for their high Young’s modulus and large specific surface area [28–30]. In addition, nanosilica with controllable particle size can easily be prepared by Stöber method [31], and it is easy to introduce new groups to achieve the desired hydrophobic nanosilica [32,33]. Particularly, recent investigation by Zhuang et al. demonstrated that a superhydrophobic surface was prepared using bisphenol A-based epoxy and silane treated commercial nanosilica, 45.5 wt% silica content afforded 153◦ water contact angle [34]. Guo et al. demonstrated that microscale PET fibres, covered with a layer of nanosilica particles by one-pot in situ Stöber procedure, afforded a superamphiphobic surface after perfluoro silanization [19]. In the above researches, the polymer-based superamphiphobic surface
284 X. Li et al. / Applied Surface Science 436 (2018) 283–292

s b l h

s w r e n A m s
hould expose hydrophobic nanosilica substrate as much as possile. However, the silica nanoparticles are easily aggregated, greatly imiting the efficiency of the hydrophobic substrate materials and indering their practical applications.
Electrospinning is a simple and effective method of producng polymeric and nanocomposite particles on a micro/nano-scale 35–37]. Electrospinning technique was applied to fabricate
superhydrophobic surface for many polymers and inoranic/polymer composites [38]. For example, Sun et al. prepared superhydrophobic poly (vinylidene fluoride) and modified silica 90–270 nm) nanocomposite fiber membrane by electrospinning
ethod [39]. Like electrospinning, electrospraying utilizes electrotatic energy to remove solvents from the working fluids to form olid polymeric composites [40]. According to the intensive interctions between the working fluid and the electrical force, a solid roduct in particulate form can be achieved. The uniform dispersion tate of the nanoparticles and polymer molecules in the fluids are ropagated. Thus, improving the quality of electrosprayed partiles for obtaining functional performance is a major concern in this eld. Further, coaxial electrospinning or electrospraying technique s an alternative approach to creating hierarchical micro/nano paterned structures [41,42]. More importantly, it may open a new way o facilitate fabrication of superamphiphobic membranes with the bility to precisely control nanoparticle loading, which is important or scaling up the fabrication of superamphiphobic coating.
In this research, the fabrication of superamphiphobic nanoilica/epoxy composite coating by a coaxial electrospraying method as reported. First, nano fluorinated silica was prepared by Stöber eaction and in-suit perfluoropolysilane modification. Then coaxial lectrospraying technique was used to prepare a special microano hierarchical texture of the fluorinated nano-silica and epoxy.
s shown in Fig. 1, epoxy solution was selected as the internal edium (core material), while fluorinated nano-silica dispersion olution was selected as the enveloping medium (sheath material)
xial electrospraying.
to encapsulate epoxy. The encapsulation statues of the fluorinated nano-silica during the coaxial electrospraying process were analysed. Finally, the mechanical property and durability of the prepared superamphiphobic composite coating was assessed.
2. Experimental
2.1. Materials
Epoxy (Epikote-828) was purchased from Momentive Specialty Chemicals, USA. 1H, 1H, 2H, 2H-perfluorooctyltriethoxysilane (FAS-13, 98%) was purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) (98%), ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) (28%), 4,4-diaminodiphenyl methane (DDM), ethanol (99.5%), ethanediol, ethyl acetate, acetone and acetic acid were all purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. Deionized water purified in an ultrapure water system (Nano pure) was used in all the experiments. All materials were used as received.
2.2. Sample preparation
2.2.1. Preparation of fluorinated silica nanoparticles The colloidal silica sol was prepared via the sol-gel process according to Stöber method [31]. Firstly, 0.1 mol TEOS and 0.72 mol ethanol were mixed and stirred in a flask at 50 ◦C for 30min. 0.02 mol NH4OH, 0.4 mol deionized water and 0.08 mol ethanol were mixed, and then added to the above TEOS pre-hydrolyzed solution and stirred at 50 ◦C for 8 h to obtain the sol. The mixture was thoroughly washed with ethanol followed by centrifugation at a speed of 10,000 rpm for 10 min, then some ethanol was added to the precipitate and ultra-sonicated for the next centrifugation, repeated for five times. The resulting precipitate was dried at 70 ◦C for 2 h and then vacuum dried at 100 ◦C for about 12 h, and the obtained nanosilica was named as SiO2. Through the same pro-

X. Li et al. / Applied Surfac
ess, FAS-13 with molar ratio of 0.02:1 for TEOS was added directly o the above silica sol, and stirred at 50 ◦C for another 12 h. Then he mixture was centrifuged, washed, and dried in the same way. he obtained product was referred to as fluoro-functionalized SiO2, oded as F-SiO2.
.2.2. Preparation of composite coating The core solution was prepared by dissolving 0.5–1.0 g epoxy nd curing agent DDM with 25:7 mass ration in 10 mL ethyl acetate. he sheath solution was prepared by dissolving less epoxy, i.e. 0.15- .5 g epoxy, and DDM (with the same 25:7 mass ration) in 10 mL thyl acetate, stirred for 30 min, added 0.1-1.0 g of F-SiO2, stirred or 1 h, and ultra-sonicated for 4 h.
The coaxial electrospraying spinneret was homemade. Two yringe pumps (KDS100, Cole-Parmer, Vernon Hills, IL) and a igh-voltage power supply (ZGF 60 kV/2 mA, Shanghai Sute Corp., hanghai, China) were used for electrospraying. The collector comrised a flat piece of cardboard wrapped with aluminium foil. All lectrospraying processes were carried out under ambient conitions (21 ± 5 ◦C with a relative humidity of 49 ± 7%). Through re-experiments, the core flow rate was selected as 0.8 mL/h and heath flow rate was 1.2 mL/h. Following optimization, the applied oltage was set as 10–14 kV, and the spinneret-to-collector disance was fixed at 15 cm. The schematic of coaxial electrospraying s shown in Fig. 1.
For comparison, F-SiO2 and epoxy composite coatings were btained by homotaxial electrospraying and manually brushing poxy and F-SiO2 mixture solution on a cleaned aluminium foil. he homotaxial electrospraying was realized by setting the core ow rate as zero in the same coaxial electrospraying device, while he sheath flow rate was selected as 1.0 mL/h. The applied voltge for homotaxial electrospraying was set as 8–9 kV, and the pinneret-to-collector distance was fixed at 15 cm. To evaluate the erformance of this coating, the content of F-SiO2 was kept in line ith the coaxial electrospraying process. All the prepared coatngs were dried for about 30 min, and then precured at 70 ◦C for h and followed by vacuum cured at 150 ◦C for 4 h. The prepared oating was named as F-SiO2/epoxy coating according to different reparation methods.
.3. Characterization
The morphology of the prepared samples in the form of nanoparicle or coating was examined via scanning electron microscopy SEM; QUANTA FEG 450 SEM) at an accelerating voltage of 20 kV fter coating with thin layers of gold. FTIR spectroscopy (Specrum 100, Perkin Elmer Co., Ltd., USA) was applied to analyse he chemical structures of the prepared nanosilica. The spectra mploying pellets of potassium bromide were collected for each easurement over a spectral range of 400–4000 cm−1. Thermoravimetric analysis (TGA; Q500, TA Co., Ltd., USA) was applied or the nanosilica. The samples (5–8 mg) were heated from ambint temperature to 800 ◦C. The heating rate was set at 15 ◦C /min nitrogen atmosphere, flow rate of 20 mL/min). X-ray photoelecron spectroscopy (XPS; ESCALAB 250X, Thermo Fisher Scientific o., Ltd., USA) was performed to determine the elemental conentrations of the nanosilica, equipped with a monochromated Al X-ray source, operating at 40 and 100 eV pass energies for the arrow region and survey spectra, respectively.
Water and ethanediol contact angle and roll-off angle of the omposite coating were measured with a DSA30 KRUSS GMBH, rom the images measured after the 5 L drop became stable for 5 s, nd the average values were recorded as an average of five tests. anoindentation (Agilent Nano G200) with a Berkovich diamond ndenter was performed to investigate the nanomechanical proprties of the coating samples, which were fixed on a glass slide by
nce 436 (2018) 283–292 285
double adhesive tape. With the depth of impression set at approximately 500 nm, the elastic modulus and hardness values were the average of 8 points.
The coating durability was measured by immersion test and scotch tape test [43]. The water and ethanediol contact angles of the coating were recorded after 0–24 h immersion in deionized water, acetone and acetic acid solution (adjust pH to 3). In the scotch tape test, the prepared coating was fixed on a glass slide, the scotch tape was pressed against the coating with 100 g loading for 1 min, and then peeled off, repeated for 10 times.
The chemical structures of the silica particles were investigated through FTIR, as shown in Fig. 3. The absorbing peaks at 1104, 809 and 469 cm−1 were the asymmetric stretching, symmetric stretching, and bending vibration of Si—O–Si, while the band at around 953 cm−1 was the out-of-plane bending vibration of –OH [44]. For F-SiO2, the above absorptions intensity was considerably weak, and a new peak at 668 cm−1 appeared for –CF2 bending vibration. A broad absorption band at 1150–1280 cm−1 region was attributed to the stretching vibration of –CF2, which was hidden by the strong Si—O–Si peaks.
The chemical compositions of the prepared nanosilica were analysed through XPS as shown in Fig. 4. The high-resolution regions of Si2p, F1s, O1s, and C1s are shown in Fig. 4b–e.
The peak at 103.41 eV in the Si2p spectrum (Fig. 4b) was assigned to the Si—O species in the SiO2-based network. For F-SiO2, the Si2p peak was higher and broader than that of the pristine SiO2. Meanwhile, the peak at 685.85 eV in the F1s spectrum (Fig. 4c) was derived from the covalent C–F bonds [45]. The XPS O1s spectra of pristine SiO2 indicated that oxygen was in a single state (Fig. 4d), and the binding energy at 532.85 eV was represented by Si—O vibrations. After in-suit modification, the O1s signals for FSiO2 represented broader peak and shifted to 533.00 eV. Broad O1s peak indicated superposition and the presence of different chemical states of oxygen. The XPS C1s spectrum (Fig. 4e) for pristine SiO2 at 284.90 and 286.50 eV corresponded to the C—C and C—O groups, which can be explained as incomplete hydrolysis and condensation of TEOS. For F-SiO2 the C1s was broader, with more complicated shape at higher spectra. Interaction between perfluoropolysilane and the in-suit synthesized F-SiO2 nanoparticles was the main reason for the various manifestations of C1s signals, which agreed with the findings on the O1s and Si2p spectra. The FTIR and XPS results revealed that perfluoropolysilane was introduced to the surface of the F-SiO2 by chemical bonding.
Fig. 5 shows the TG curves for the pristine and F-SiO2 under nitrogen atmosphere. The tardy loss process of pristine SiO2 less than 100 ◦C can be attributed to the mass loss of moisture. For F-SiO2, the weight loss before 400 ◦C was less, especially for the temperatures below 120 ◦C, indicating a hydrophobic surface and improved thermal stability. The sharp mass loss process of F-SiO2 above 450 ◦C can be attributed to the thermal decomposition of the long fluorocarbon chain. Compared with the pristine SiO2, the char residual (at 800 ◦C) of F-SiO2 was 73.4%, which was 16.8% less than that of pristine SiO2, indicating that F-SiO2 with more than 15wt% perfluoropolysilane grafting.

.2. Contact and rolling angle of coating
The wettability of the epoxy and its composite coating was ompared using different methods, namely, manual brushing, omotaxial electrospraying, and coaxial electrospraying method.
hatever the preparing method, the water contact angles of epoxy oating without F-SiO2 were all about 70◦. The hydrophobicity of -SiO2/epoxy composites coating increased with F-SiO2 content. evertheless, the water contact angles of the manual brushed com-
pristine SiO2, (c)(d) F-SiO2.
posite coating were less than 110◦ even for F-SiO2 content up to 50 wt%.
The water contact angle of the homotaxial electrosprayed FSiO2/epoxy coating was 135 ± 3◦ at mass ratio 1:2.5 for the F-SiO2 and epoxy, about 23.8 wt % F-SiO2 content for considering DDM. While for the coaxial electrosprayed F-SiO2/epoxy coating with the same mass ratio for the F-SiO2 and epoxy in the sheath solution (about 9.4 wt % F-SiO2 content for considering epoxy and DDM in core solution), its water contact angle improved to 145 ± 2◦. The coaxial electrosprayed coating showed significantly higher water contact angle than that of the homotaxial electrosprayed coating.
For the coaxial electrosprayed F-SiO2/epoxy coating with 15.3 wt% F-SiO2 content, the water and ethanediol contact angles were 165 ± 3◦ and 152 ± 3◦, and the corresponding rolling angles were 3 ± 1◦ and 18 ± 2◦, respectively. When the F-SiO2 content reached 28.1 wt%, the water/ethanediol contact and rolling angles of the coating were as high as 170 ± 2◦/158 ± 3◦ and 2 ± 1◦/7 ± 2◦, respectively. Furthermore, common household liquids, such as milk and ink, existed as ball-like droplets on the coating, shown in Fig. 6. The coaxial electrosprayed F-SiO2/epoxy coating exhibited good superamphiphobic and anti-sticking properties.
3.3. Morphology of the coating
The surface morphology of the as-prepared coating was investigated by SEM analysis given in Fig. 7. The morphology of the F-SiO2/epoxy composites coating was compared by homotaxial electrospraying (Fig. 7a) and coaxial electrospraying method

As shown in Fig. 7a, F-SiO2/epoxy particle size prepared by omotaxial electrospraying method was loose and not uniform. The -SiO2/epoxy particle size prepared by homotaxial electrosprayng was 8.9 ± 6.5 m, which could be derived from the histogram counted from 100 individual particles) in the inset of Fig. 7a. Fig. 7b howed that the coaxial electrosprayed particle size was 9.3 ± 7.5 m, presented a normal distribution from 2 to 17 m. According o the amplifying photograph (Fig. 7c and d), F-SiO2 with uniorm nano-size was distributed evenly on the epoxy microparticles, roviding additional nanoscale roughness. The prepared raspberryike F-SiO2/epoxy microspheres contained both micrometer and anometer-scale roughness like lotus leaves [46]. With 165 ± 3◦ nd 152 ± 3◦ water and ethanediol contact angles, superamphiphoic F-SiO2/epoxy coating was realized in the case of 15.3wt% F-SiO2 ontent in the coaxial electrostatic spraying process. Superamhiphobic as well as the superior anti-sticking performance of the repared coating with limited F-SiO2 content could be attributed to he additional uniform nanoscale structure enabled by the F-SiO2 n the surface of individual epoxy microparticles.
In addition, from Fig. 7d, the mean particle size of F-SiO2 on he epoxy microparticle was 126 ± 28 nm, slightly larger than that
The coaxial electrosprayed F-SiO2/epoxy superamphiphobic coating was characterized with a Nano Scratch Tester. Fig. 8 shows the indentation load – depth curves for the coating sample. Epoxy coating without F-SiO2 control sample was also prepared by the same coaxial electrospraying method.
X. Li et al. / Applied Surface Science 436 (2018) 283–292 289
(with 15.3wt% F-SiO2) coating prepared by coaxial electrospraying method.

The load of the F-SiO2/epoxy coating before 150 nm nanondentation displacement was smaller than that of the raw epoxy oating, which can be attributed to some loosely bonded FiO2 on the outer surface of the epoxy particles. However, with ncreased loading process, the F-SiO2/epoxy composite coating xhibited improved loading force, and similarly a sharper unloadng curve. Notably, the corresponding unloading segment in the oad-displacement curve showed an obvious discontinuity (blue ashed ellipse in Fig. 8). During loading, the coating underneath he indenter was pressed into the aluminium substrate. However, uring unloading, the coating was detached from the substrate and ehaved like a spring, pushing the indenter out of the impression nd generating an extra load at lower depths than normal elastic nloading [47]. The deeper the indenter went into the substrate, he more obvious the interfacial discontinuity in the corresponding oad-displacement curve. The above discontinuity for F-SiO2/epoxy oating was less evident than that of the epoxy coating, indicatng a stronger interaction between the F-SiO2/epoxy coating and he substrate. The modulus and hardness of the F-SiO2/epoxy coatng were 3.434 ± 0.716 and 0.272 ± 0.104 GPa (2.657 ± 0.107 and .235 ± 0.005 GPa for that of the epoxy coating), respectively, which ere 30% and 16% higher than those of the epoxy coating. The reinorcement effect of F-SiO2 on the epoxy coating was evident. The -SiO2/epoxy coating after nano-indentation test was examined nder SEM, as shown in Fig. 9.
At the 500 nm maximum indenter displacement, SEM microraph exhibited a sharp indent mark, and no cracks can be observed. ome epoxy microparticles were flattened by the nano-indentation yramidal indenter (Fig. 9a). A certain number of the bonded F-SiO2 anoparticles were dropped from the epoxy particle and squeezed o the substrate (Fig. 9b). The micro-nano structure of epoxy and -SiO2 can provide efficient stress transfer to resist the indentation oading, which explained the evident reinforcement effect of the -SiO2 nanoparticles on the epoxy coating.
.5. Durability of the coating
The durability of the superamphiphobic surface is an imporant aspect of these composite coatings. After more than 10
onths preserved in natural conditions, the coaxial electrosprayed -SiO2/epoxy (with 15.3 wt% F-SiO2) coating maintained good uperamphiphobic status. Fig. 10 shows the curves of water and thanediol contact angles variation of the F-SiO2/epoxy coating for 4h immersion test. The water contact angle kept unchanged at 65◦ ± 3◦ after 24 h deionized water immersion test, while slightly ecreased to 162◦ ± 2◦ and 158◦ ± 2◦ after 24 h acetic acid and cetone solution immersion test. The ethanediol contact angles
also slightly decreased from 152◦ ± 3◦ to 146 ± 3◦, 148◦ ± 3◦ and 145◦ ± 2◦ for deionized water, acetic acid solution and acetone 24 h immersion. The prepared coating maintained good superhydrophobic status, indicating that the coating has good chemical stability.
The above F-SiO2/epoxy coating after 24 h acetone immersion was examined under SEM, as shown in Fig. 11.
As shown in Fig. 11a, no crack or exfoliate can be observed, acetone had minimal damage to the coating. The raspberry-like F-SiO2/epoxy micro-nano structure and the diameter of the FSiO2 nanoparticles were nearly unchanged after the 24 h strong polar solvent immersion test. While the decreased contact angle after long time acetone immersion can be explained as the insufficient crosslink density of the epoxy microparticles [48]. During the electrospraying process, the intensive interactions between the working fluid and the electrical force may incompletely remove solvents from the core solution and the sheath solution. It was not easy to obtain high crosslink density network for all of the electrosprayed epoxy microparticles. Those epoxy microparticles without enough F-SiO2 nanoparticles protection may partly be attacked from the acetone solvent. Fortunately, according to the sufficient F-SiO2 encapsulation, the F-SiO2/epoxy composite coating maintained superhydrophobic after the long-time acetone immersion, indicating that enough and well bonded F-SiO2 has unprecedented chemical stability.

epoxy microparticles were peeled off from the coating (Fig. 12c). Fig. 12d demonstrated that the integrity of the raspberry-like FSiO2/epoxy structure was largely maintained, only tiny stains were left on the area without enough F-SiO2 nanoparticles protection

red arrow in Fig. 12d). The scotch tape test indicated that enough nd well bonded F-SiO2 had good anti-sticking effect, while the eeled off epoxy microparticles suggested the direction for the folowing study.
. Conclusions
Fluorinated nano-silica with uniform diameter and stable hemical bonding was prepared by sol-gel method and in suit peruoropolysilane modification. F-SiO2 and epoxy composite coating ith micro-nano hierarchical structures was successfully contructed by the coaxial electrospraying method. When the F-SiO2 ontent reached 15.3 wt%, the water and ethanediol contact angles f the coaxial electrosprayed F-SiO2/epoxy composite coating eached 165 ± 3◦ and 152 ± 3◦, respectively, showing a superamhiphobic and good anti-sticking status. According to the intensive nteractions between the core/sheath fluid and the electrical force uring the coaxial electrospraying process, F-SiO2 nanoparticles omogeneously encapsulated the epoxy microparticles. The speial raspberry-like F-SiO2/epoxy structure can greatly increase the tilization efficiency of the fluorinated nano-silica. Evident reinorcement effect of the F-SiO2 nanoparticles on the epoxy coating as realized by efficient stress transfer for the hierarchical microano structure, showing improved modulus and hardness in the ano-indentation test. In addition, the prepared F-SiO2/epoxy comosite coating can resist damage from strong polar organic solvent nd repeated sticky, which can broaden the fields of application. he coaxial electrospraying technique is an alternative approach to reate special hierarchical structure. It opens a new way to facilitate abrication of superamphiphobic coating capable of fully utilizing he functional nanoparticles, which is important for scaling up the abrication of superamphiphobic polymer-based nanocomposite oating.

referenceMentions.context: Superhydrophobic and superamphiphobic surfaces have ttracted extensive interests in the past decades owing to their nique self-cleaning property [1,2].
Superhydrophobic and superamphiphobic surfaces have ttracted extensive interests in the past decades owing to their nique self-cleaning property [1,2].
Superamphiphobic coating was prepared by various methods, uch as chemical vapor deposition [6], electrochemical etchng [7], sol–gel [8], and solution–immersion method [9].
Superamphiphobic coating was prepared by various methods, uch as chemical vapor deposition [6], electrochemical etchng [7], sol–gel [8], and solution–immersion method [9].
Superamphiphobic coating was prepared by various methods, uch as chemical vapor deposition [6], electrochemical etchng [7], sol–gel [8], and solution–immersion method [9].
The polymer-based hierarchical surface could be generated by using different inorganic materials, such as nano-silica [19,20], carbon nanofibers [21], titanium dioxide [1], and others [22].

metadata.abstractText: In this study, a durable superamphiphobic nano-silica and epoxy composite coating with good environment resistant was successfully fabricated. Fluorinated nano-silica with low surface energy was prepared by in situ sol-gel method, which can be stably dispersed in the solution. Applying fluorinated nano-silica dispersion as sheath and epoxy solution as core, fluorinated nano-silica/epoxy superamphiphobic composite coating was prepared by a coaxial electrospraying method. Fluorinated nano-silica with uniform nano-size was distributed evenly on the micro epoxy particles, showing a special micro-nano hierarchical
metadata.creator: Elsevier
